content:

comments.content:
You can do this in the Illustrator as well using the same filters(Effect/Pixelate/Color Halftone) but here am showing how to do it in the Photoshop.

Create a big black dot on a transparent layer with a white background

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012144605im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/1_3732.jpg)
  
apply gaussian blur to the dot layer  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012144605im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/2_4943.jpg)
  
Now merge all the layers(Ctrl+Shift+E) and apply halftone effect with following details.  
(Filter/Pixelate/Color Halftone)  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012144605im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/3_4023.jpg)
  
Then you can take this image to Illustrator and apply live trace filter to get a verctor output.  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012144605im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/5_5183.jpg)
Note: You can run the color noise filter more than once to get the effect you want - repeat applications to the effect seem to widen it.

I just came across a good tutorial on this:  
 [http://vectips.com/tutorials/creating-halftone-effects/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012144605/http:/vectips.com/tutorials/creating-halftone-effects/)

there are also a few tools/tutorials for creating this  
kind of effect at [bittbox](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012144605/http:/www.bittbox.com/illustrator/bb-special-3-ways-vector-halftones-from-raster-images/)
